page.title: Pronouns and Proper Names - Reflexives
page.introduction:
Reflexives are another type of pronouns that most languages have. They occur only in the same case as direct objects and normally must agree with the subject in person, gender, and number features. Examples in English are: herself,himself, themselves, myself. Some languages have a completely separate set of pronoun forms for reflexives, others use a phrase which consists of a noun (usually meaning ‘self’) that is possessed by the pronoun that refers back to the subject, and some languages do not distinguish between reflexive and regular pronouns.
[Note that this starterkit does not enforce agreement between the reflexive and the subject; it only allows reflexives to parse. Therefore, examples such as The girl saw yourself will not be ruled out. See the Advanced Help file to add such enforced agreement if needed for your language.]

radioGroup.prompt: Are the reflexive pronouns built by adding an affix to other pronouns, as in English?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, one or more affixes are chosen among to make another pronoun reflexive
No, they are distinct, stand alone words
No, a phrase consisting of a certain noun with a pronoun as the possessor is used

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature reflexive to the relevant affixes.

In the lexicon, mark each reflexive pronoun with the feature reflexive and also all the relevant
person (first, first_exclusive, first_inclusive, second, third),
number (singular, dual, plural), and
gender (masculine, feminine, neuter) features.
Also, add the appropriate case feature (accusative, absolutive).
In the lexicon, add the feature reflexive to the relevant noun.
